Welcome to homework14’s documentation!¶

homework14’s Main¶

main.healthchecker(db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The healthchecker function is a simple function that checks the health of the database. It does this by making a request to the database and checking if it returns any results. If there are no results, then we know something is wrong with our connection.

Parameters:

db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A dictionary with a message

Doc-author:

Trelent

async main.limit_access_by_ip(request: Request, call_next: Callable)¶

The limit_access_by_ip function is a middleware function that limits access to the API by IP address. It checks if the client’s IP address is in ALLOWED_IPS, and if not, returns a 403 Forbidden response.

Parameters:

  • request – Request: Get the client’s ip address

  • call_next – Callable: Pass the next function in the chain

Returns:

A jsonresponse object with a status code of 403 and a detail message

Doc-author:

Trelent

async main.root()¶

The root function returns a JSON object with the message &quot;Hello World&quot;.

Returns:

A dictionary with a single key &quot;message&quot; and the value of that key is &quot;hello world&quot;

Doc-author:

Trelent

async main.startup()¶

The startup function is called when the application starts up. It’s a good place to initialize things that are needed by your app, such as connecting to databases or initializing caches.

Returns:

A list of coroutines to run

Doc-author:

Trelent

homework14’s Database¶

src.database.db.get_db()¶

The get_db function is a context manager that will automatically close the database session at the end of a request. It also handles any exceptions that occur during the request, and aborts with an HTTP 400 error if one occurs.

Returns:

A database connection, which is used by all the functions that need to query the database

Doc-author:

Trelent

homework14’s Contacts¶

async src.repository.contacts.create(body: ContactModel, current_user: User, db: Session)¶

The create function creates a new contact in the database.

Parameters:

  • body – ContactModel: Get the data from the request body

  • current_user – User: Check if the user is authenticated

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

The contact model

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.contacts.get_contact_by_birth_date(birth_date: date, user: User, db: Session)¶
The get_contact_by_birth_date function returns a contact object from the database based on the birth_date parameter.
The function takes in three parameters:

  • birth_date: A date object representing the birthday of a contact.

  • user: A User object representing an authenticated user. This is used to ensure that only contacts belonging to this user are returned by this function.

  • db: An SQLAlchemy Session instance, which is used for querying and updating data in our database.

Parameters:

  • birth_date – date: Filter the contacts by birth date

  • user – User: Get the user_id from the user object

  • db – Session: Pass a database session to the function

Returns:

The contact with the specified birth date and user id

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.contacts.get_contact_by_email(email: str, user: User, db: Session)¶
The get_contact_by_email function takes in an email and a user, and returns the contact with that email.
Args:

email (str): The contact’s unique identifier. user (User): The current logged-in user.

Parameters:

  • email – str: Pass in the email of the contact we want to find

  • user – User: Identify the user that is making the request

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

The contact with the given email and user

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.contacts.get_contact_by_first_name(first_name: str, user: User, db: Session)¶

The get_contact_by_first_name function takes in a first_name and user object, and returns the contact with that first name. If no such contact exists, it returns None.

Parameters:

  • first_name – str: Filter the database for contacts with a matching first name

  • user – User: Identify the user who is making the request

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A contact object

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.contacts.get_contact_by_id(contact_id: int, user: User, db: Session)¶
The get_contact_by_id function takes in a contact_id and user, and returns the contact with that id.
Args:

contact_id (int): The id of the desired Contact object. user (User): The User object associated with this request.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Specify the id of the contact that is being retrieved

  • user – User: Get the user id from the user object

  • db – Session: Pass a database session to the function

Returns:

The contact with the given id

  • phone – str: Get the phone number of a contact

  • user – User: Filter the contacts by user

  • db – Session: Access the database

  • db – Session: Access the database

async src.repository.contacts.get_contacts(limit: int, offset: int, user: User, db: Session)¶

The get_contacts function returns a list of contacts for the user.

Parameters:

  • limit – int: Limit the number of contacts returned

  • offset – int: Skip a certain number of contacts

  • user – User: Get the user id from the database

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

A list of contacts

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.contacts.get_contacts_birthday(start_date: date, end_date: date, db: Session)¶

The get_contacts_birthday function returns a list of contacts whose birthdays fall between the start_date and end_date. The function takes in three parameters:

  • start_date: The first date to check for birthdays (inclusive)

  • end_date: The last date to check for birthdays (inclusive)

  • db: A database session object that is used to query the database. This parameter is automatically passed by FastAPI when you use dependency injection.

Parameters:

  • start_date – date: Set the start date of the range

  • end_date – date: Set the end date of the range

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A list of contacts whose birthdays are between the start date and end date

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.contacts.remove(contact_id: int, user: User, db: Session)¶
The remove function removes a contact from the database.
Args:

contact_id (int): The id of the contact to be removed. user (User): The user who is removing the contact. db (Session): A connection to our database, used for querying and updating data.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Specify the id of the contact to be removed

  • user – User: Check if the user is logged in

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

The contact that was removed, if it exists

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.contacts.update(contact_id: int, body: ContactModel, user: User, db: Session)¶
The update function updates a contact in the database.
Args:

contact_id (int): The id of the contact to update. body (ContactModel): The updated information for the specified user.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Identify the contact to be deleted

  • body – ContactModel: Pass the data from the request body to the function

  • user – User: Get the user_id from the token

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

The updated contact

Parameters:

  • refresh_token – Update the user’s refresh token in the database

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

Nothing

homework14’s routes Auth¶

async src.routes.auth.confirmed_email(token: str, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The confirmed_email function is used to confirm a user’s email address.

It takes the token from the URL and uses it to get the user’s email address. Then, it checks if that user exists in our database. If not, we return an error message saying so. If they do exist, we check if their account has already been confirmed or not (if they’ve already clicked on this link). If their account has been confirmed, we return a message saying so; otherwise, we update their record in our database by setting &quot;confirmed&quot; to True and then return another success message.

Parameters:

  • token – str: Get the token from the url

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A message that the email is already confirmed or a message that the email was confirmed

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.auth.login(body: OAuth2PasswordRequestForm = Depends(NoneType), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The login function is used to authenticate a user.

It takes the username and password from the request body, verifies them against the database, and returns an access token if successful.

Parameters:

  • body – OAuth2PasswordRequestForm: Get the username and password from the request body

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A dictionary with the access_token, refresh_token and token type

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.auth.refresh_token(credentials: HTTPAuthorizationCredentials = Security(HTTPBearer), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The refresh_token function is used to refresh the access token.

The function takes in a refresh token and returns an access_token, a new refresh_token, and the type of token. If the user’s current refresh_token does not match what was passed into this function then it will return an error.

Parameters:

  • credentials – HTTPAuthorizationCredentials: Get the token from the request header

  • db – Session: Create a database session

Returns:

A new access_token and refresh_token

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.auth.request_email(body: RequestEmail, background_task: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The request_email function is used to send an email to the user with a link that will confirm their account.

The function takes in a RequestEmail object, which contains the user’s email address. It then checks if there is already an account associated with that email address and whether or not it has been confirmed yet. If it hasn’t been confirmed, we add a task to our background_task queue (which was passed into this function) using FastAPI’s BackgroundTasks class and call our send_email() function from utils/mailer.py.

Parameters:

  • body – RequestEmail: Get the email from the request body

  • background_task – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background tasks queue

  • request – Request: Get the base_url of the server

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A message to the user, but it also adds a task to the background_task object

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.auth.signup(body: UserModel, background_task: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The signup function creates a new user in the database.

It takes in a UserModel object, which is validated by pydantic. The password is hashed using Argon2 and stored as such.

Parameters:

  • body – UserModel: Get the user information from the request body

  • background_task – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background tasks queue

  • request – Request: Get the base url of the request

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

The newly created user, but it also sends an email to the new user

Doc-author:

Trelent

Trelent

src.routes.contacts.get_contact(contact_id: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: Contact = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The get_contact function returns a ContactResponse object, which is the same as a Contact model. The function takes in an integer contact_id and uses it to query the database for that specific contact. If no such contact exists, then an HTTPException is raised with status code 404 (Not Found). Otherwise, if the user does exist in the database, then their information will be returned.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Specify the id of the contact to be retrieved

  • db – Session: Get the database session

  • current_user – Contact: Get the current user

Returns:

A contactresponse object, which is the same as a contact object but without the user_id attribute

Doc-author:

Trelent

src.routes.contacts.upcoming_birthdays(db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The upcoming_birthdays function returns a list of contacts with birthdays in the next week.

Parameters:

db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

A list of contactresponse objects

Doc-author:

Trelent

src.routes.contacts.update_contact(contact_id: int, contact: ContactCreateUpdate, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: Contact = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The update_contact function updates a contact in the database.

It takes an id, a ContactCreateUpdate object, and optionally a db Session and current_user. If no user is provided it will use the auth_service to get one from the Authorization header of the request. The function then queries for that contact in our database using its id and user_id (to ensure only contacts belonging to that user are updated). If no such contact exists we raise an HTTPException with status code 404 (Not Found) and detail &quot;Contact not found&quot;.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Identify the contact to be updated

  • contact – ContactCreateUpdate: Pass the contact data to update

  • db – Session: Get the database session

  • current_user – Contact: Get the current user from the database

Returns:

A contactresponse object

Doc-author:

Trelent

ALGORITHM = 'HS256'¶
SECRET_KEY = 'secret_key'¶
async create_access_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None)¶
The create_access_token function creates a new access token for the user.
Args:

data (dict): A dictionary containing the user’s id and username. expires_delta (Optional[float]): The time in seconds until the token expires. Defaults to 15 minutes if not specified.

Parameters:

  • self – Refer to the class itself

  • data – dict: Pass in the data that will be encoded into the token

  • expires_delta – Optional[float]: Set the expiration time of the access token

Returns:

A string

Doc-author:

Trelent

create_email_token(data: dict)¶

The create_email_token function takes a dictionary of data and returns a token. The token is encoded with the SECRET_KEY, which is stored in the .env file. The algorithm used to encode the token is also stored in the .env file.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • data – dict: Pass in the user’s email address

Returns:

A token

Doc-author:

Trelent

async create_refresh_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None)¶
The create_refresh_token function creates a refresh token for the user.
Args:

data (dict): A dictionary containing the user’s id and username. expires_delta (Optional[float]): The number of seconds until the token expires, defaults to None.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • data – dict: Pass in the data that will be encoded into the token

  • expires_delta – Optional[float]: Set the expiry time of the refresh token

Returns:

A refresh token that is encoded with the user’s id, username, and email

Doc-author:

Trelent

async decode_refresh_token(refresh_token: str)¶

The decode_refresh_token function is used to decode the refresh token. It takes a refresh_token as an argument and returns the email of the user if it’s valid. If not, it raises an HTTPException with status code 401 (UNAUTHORIZED) and detail ‘Could not validate credentials’.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • refresh_token – str: Pass in the refresh token that was sent to the client

Returns:

The email of the user who is trying to refresh their access token

Doc-author:

Trelent

async get_current_user(token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The get_current_user function is a dependency that will be used in the

protected endpoints. It takes a token as an argument and returns the user if it’s valid, otherwise raises an HTTPException with status code 401.

Parameters:

  • self – Access the class attributes

  • token – str: Get the token from the request header

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

The user object

Doc-author:

Trelent

get_email_from_token(token: str)¶

The get_email_from_token function takes a token as an argument and returns the email associated with that token. If the scope of the token is not ‘email_token’, then it raises an HTTPException. If there is a JWTError, it also raises an HTTPException.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • token – str: Pass in the token that is sent to the user’s email

Returns:

The email that was passed in the payload of the jwt token

Doc-author:

Trelent

get_password_hash(password: str)¶

The get_password_hash function takes a password as input and returns the hash of that password. The hash is generated using the pwd_context object, which is an instance of Flask-Bcrypt’s Bcrypt class.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • password – str: Pass the password to be hashed into the function

Returns:

A string that is the hash of the password

Doc-author:

Trelent

oauth2_scheme = <fastapi.security.oauth2.OAuth2PasswordBearer object>¶
pwd_context = <CryptContext>¶
r = Redis<ConnectionPool<Connection<host=localhost,port=6379,db=0>>>¶
verify_password(plain_password, hashed_password)¶

The verify_password function takes a plain-text password and hashed password as arguments. It then uses the pwd_context object to verify that the plain-text password matches the hashed one.

Parameters:

  • self – Make the method a bound method, which means that it can be called on objects of this class

  • plain_password – Pass in the password that the user enters when they log in

  • hashed_password – Compare the plain_password parameter to see if they match

Returns:

A boolean value

Doc-author:

Trelent

homework14’s services Cloud_image¶

class src.services.cloud_image.CloudImage¶

Bases: object

static generate_name_avatar(email: str)¶

The generate_name_avatar function takes an email address as input and returns a unique name for the avatar image. The function uses the SHA256 hash of the email address to generate a 12-character string, which is then used as part of the filename for the avatar image.

Parameters:

email – str: Tell the function that it will be receiving a string as an argument

Returns:

A string that is the name of an avatar

Doc-author:

Trelent

static get_url_for_avatar(public_id, r)¶

The get_url_for_avatar function takes in a public_id and an r (which is the result of a cloudinary.api.resource call) and returns the URL for that avatar image, which will be used to display it on the page.

Parameters:

  • public_id – Identify the image in cloudinary

  • r – Get the version of the image

Returns:

The url of the avatar image

Doc-author:

Trelent

static upload(file, public_id: str)¶

The upload function takes a file and public_id as arguments. The function then uploads the file to Cloudinary using the public_id provided. If no public_id is provided, one will be generated automatically.

Parameters:

  • file – Upload the file to cloudinary

  • public_id – str: Specify the public id of the image

Returns:

A dictionary with the following keys:

Doc-author:

Trelent

homework14’s services Email¶

async src.services.email.send_email(email: EmailStr, username: str, host: str)¶
The send_email function sends an email to the user with a link that they can click on to verify their email address.
The function takes in three parameters:

-email: the user’s email address, which is used as a unique identifier for each account. -username: the username of the account being created. This is included in case there are multiple accounts associated with one email address, so that we know which account we’re verifying when sending out emails. -host: this parameter contains information about where our application is hosted (i.e., localhost or Heroku). It’s needed because it will be

Parameters:

  • email – EmailStr: Specify the type of parameter that is expected

  • username – str: Pass the username of the user to be sent an email

  • host – str: Pass the hostname of the server to the email template

Returns:

The result of the await fm

Doc-author:

Trelent
